docs.lead_paragraph: You're not getting older. You're getting more sober. Researchers from the University of California, Los Angeles have found that as people age, their alcohol consumption goes down. The report appears in the March issue of The American Journal of Public Health.
docs.abstract: Dr Alison A Moore of University of California, Los Angeles, leads research that shows alcohol consumption goes down as people age; study, published in American Journal of Public Health, used data from series of federal health surveys to identify trend; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Researchers have found that as people age, their alcohol consumption goes down.

docs.lead_paragraph: On a sparkling hot Florida day, I walked from an elevator into a small dark lobby and strode out the open door at speed. Except that the door wasn't open. It was an unmarked sheet of clean clear glass that clobbered me on the forehead two inches above my right eye. I didn't pass out, see double, grow confused or feel nauseated. I did feel shaken, though, drove straight home, iced the area and rested.

headline.main: A Journey Through Concussion's Foggy Terrain

docs.abstract: Diane Ackerman Cases column describes symptoms of concussion and potential lingering physical problems one might experience after suffering head injury; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: With mild concussions like the author's, sometimes the aftershocks can last far beyond the initial injury.
